historicalDescription: Located in the Castello sestiere, this area was known for its workshops producing wooden planks and boards for construction, especially for building and repairing ships at the nearby Arsenale.

canalPoints.historicalDescription: This dock was named after the woodturners who had workshops nearby in Calle de le Tole. These artisans specialized in creating wooden balusters, furniture legs, and decorative elements using lathes - crafts essential to Venice's furniture industry during the Renaissance.

This landing was where timber planks were delivered and unloaded for the various woodworking shops in Calle de le Tole. The name reflects the area's historical connection to woodworking, as 'tole' itself refers to wooden planks or boards in Venetian dialect.

The Marangoni were the guild of carpenters and joiners in Renaissance Venice. This dock served their workshops that were concentrated in the Calle de le Tole area, where they crafted everything from ornate furniture to architectural elements for Venice's palaces and churches.

canalPoints.englishName: Shore of Saints John and Paul
canalPoints.historicalDescription: Named for its proximity to the Basilica di San Giovanni e Paolo (locally known as San Zanipolo in Venetian dialect), one of Venice's largest churches. This dock would have served visitors and materials headed to both the basilica and the Scuola Grande di San Marco nearby from the Calle de le Tole district.

This dock was named for the falegnami (woodworkers) who were prevalent in the area of Calle de le Tole. The Falegnami guild was distinct from other woodworking specialties and focused on general carpentry. This landing would have received raw materials for their workshops that produced wooden items essential to Venetian daily life.

connection.historicalDescription: Named after the woodworkers' workshops that were historically located near Calle de le Tole. 'Tole' refers to wooden planks or boards, and this area was known for woodworking artisans who crafted furniture and wooden goods for Venetian households.

This bridge name references the early printing workshops that operated in this district during the Renaissance period. Venice was one of Europe's most important centers for printing in the 15th-16th centuries, and the area around Calle de le Tole housed several printing establishments that produced books and documents.

Named to commemorate the Armenian merchant community that established itself in this part of Venice. Armenian traders were important to Venice's commerce with the East, and they had a significant presence near Calle de le Tole, bringing valuable goods such as silk, spices, and precious stones to the Republic.

This bridge takes its name from the small educational institutions that existed in the vicinity of Calle de le Tole. Renaissance Venice had numerous small schools where young nobles and merchants' children received instruction in subjects ranging from mathematics to classical languages, preparing them for roles in commerce and governance.

buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after the woodworkers' guild (marangoni) that had workshops in this area near Calle de le Tole. Carpenters were essential for the Venetian shipbuilding industry and furniture crafting.

The stonemasons (tagiapiera) were responsible for creating the ornate stone decorations of Venetian palaces. This street housed several workshops where they would carve marble and stone for building projects.
Named after a prominent bakery that served the neighborhood around Calle de le Tole. Bakers were essential to Venetian daily life and were strictly regulated by the Republic.
Named after a small shrine with an image of the Madonna that was placed along this canal-side walkway. Such devotional markers were common throughout Venice.
This covered passageway was home to artisans who made the distinctive Venetian caps (barète). Cap makers formed their own guild and were important to Venetian fashion.

A former canal that was filled in during urban renovations, possibly named for the good water quality or for water sellers who gathered here. Rio Terà indicates a filled-in canal that became a street.
Named after the sailmakers who operated workshops in this area. Sailmaking was a crucial industry for the maritime Republic of Venice.
Named for the Greek community that settled nearby. 'Salizada' indicates one of the first paved streets in Venice, showing the importance of the Greek merchants to Venetian commerce.
Named after a public water well (pozzo) located in this small square. Wells were essential infrastructure in Venice for collecting rainwater, as the city had no natural freshwater sources.
Often named for its proximity to a church or convent, suggesting a path to spiritual paradise, or ironically named for a once-disreputable area that was later reformed.
Named after the Morosini family, a prominent noble Venetian family that produced several doges and military leaders. Their family palace was likely nearby.
A small side street named after a grain mill (pestrin) that operated in the vicinity. Grain processing was essential for the city's food supply.
Possibly named after almond sellers or confectioners who used almonds in their sweets, or for the almond-like shape of the street itself.
Named for glassmakers who may have had workshops here before the industry was concentrated on Murano. Venetian glass was world-renowned during the Renaissance.
Named after craftsmen who made wooden or ceramic bowls and dishes. These artisans were essential for producing everyday items for Venetian households.
Named after an institution that prepared converts (particularly Jews and Muslims) for baptism into Christianity, reflecting Venice's position as a crossroads of cultures and religions.
Named for its proximity to a church bell tower, which would have been a prominent landmark in the neighborhood around Calle de le Tole.
Likely named after a nearby Scuola (confraternity) dedicated to acts of mercy and charity, which were important religious and social institutions in Renaissance Venice.
Named after textile dyers who worked in this area. The textile industry was one of Venice's most important, and dyers used distinctive techniques and imported dyestuffs.
May refer to a shop selling beans, or to the Church of Santa Maria della Fava nearby. Beans were an important staple in Venetian diet.
A street where goldsmiths and jewelry makers had their workshops and stores. 'Ruga' typically indicated a commercial street lined with shops of the same trade.
Named after a business consortium or association of merchants who may have had their headquarters or warehouses in this street.
A small square directly connected to Calle de le Tole, named after the wooden planks ('tole') used in construction or sold by merchants in this area.
Named after an orphanage or charitable institution in the area. The Pietà was famously associated with Antonio Vivaldi, who taught music to orphaned girls.
A covered passageway possibly used by priests traveling between a church and rectory, or named for clerical residences nearby.
A poetically named street that was once a canal. May reference a location where philosophers or scholars gathered, or simply a quiet, contemplative area.
Named after the Contarini family, one of the founding families of Venice who produced eight doges. Their influence would have been felt throughout the city.
Named after a 'squero' or small boatyard where gondolas and other small vessels were built and repaired, essential to Venetian transportation.
A side street named after cotton fabric producers. The textile industry was crucial to Venetian commerce, with cotton being an important imported material.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Paved Way of the Spice Merchants
buildingPoints.streetDescription: One of the first paved streets in the area, named after spice merchants. Venice was the main European hub for the spice trade with the East during the Renaissance.
Named after immigrants from Friuli who settled in this area. Venice often had neighborhoods named after the regional origin of its inhabitants.
A canal-side street where goldsmiths and jewelry makers had their workshops. Venetian jewelry was famous throughout Europe for its craftsmanship.
Named after craftsmen who made spindles for the textile industry. This specialized craft supported Venice's important cloth production.
A former canal filled to create a street, named for its proximity to Franciscan friars (frari) who had a monastery in the vicinity.
